quotes.quote: There's something so familial and intimate between a boxer and his trainer.
To be a boxer is to be within yourself, inside your thoughts and feelings.
In boxing, it is about the obsession of getting the most from yourself: wanting to dominate the world like a hungry young lion.
As a boxer, you have to put risk in to get to another level.
To be knocked out doesn't mean what it seems. A boxer does not have to get up.
A boxer must exercise and develop every part of his body.
The life of a boxer is about fighting for world titles.
A boxer is like a lion, the greatest predator on land, but you throw him in the shark tank and he's just another meal.
When you're a boxer, there is a lot of downtime and long periods of inactivity.
The mere fact that a boxer covers his face never means that he is much afraid of his opponent. A good punch will give a better explanation for his action!
A boxer never sees the big one that hits him.
Just like a boxer can't win without a few punches on his face, a student can't be fully trained without ups and downs.
A boxer makes a comeback for two reasons: either he's broke or he needs the money.
No boxer in the history of boxing has had Parkinson's. There's no injury in my brain that suggests that the illness came from boxing.
Boxers, like prostitutes, are in the business of ruining their bodies for the pleasure of strangers.
